title: Doddington Hall Walks

images.title: Richard Croft / Doddington Hall
images.caption: Doddington Hall. Construction of the hall begain in 1595 by Robert Smythson, one of England’s foremost Elizabethan Architects. It was completed in 1600

images.title: Richard Croft / A parting of the ways
images.caption: A parting of the ways: An agricultural track heads off to the right as an avenue of Limes leads to the left to Doddington Hall, by the New Dairy.

images.title: Peter Church / The grounds, Doddington Hall
images.caption: The grounds, Doddington Hall. The gardens include fine topiary and seasonal flowers such as snowdrops and daffodils.

images.title: Richard Croft, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Vintage wagon

images.title: Ha-ha at Doddington Hall by Richard Green, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ha-ha at Doddington Hall

images.title: The Temple of the Winds at Doddington Hall by Richard Green, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Temple of the Winds

description: This walk explores the estate of the Elizabethan manor house of Doddington Hall, near Skellingthorpe and the city of Lincoln in North Lincolnshire. For a fee you can gain entry to the hall and its surrounding gardens. The grounds also include a number of shops and cafes including a farm shop and bike shop. Here you can find out details about the off road cycle track which is located on the southern side of the site at Pickworths Wood. This walk follows a circular public footpath around the hall estate for a distance of about 2 miles. This will take you past Strunch Hill Wood, Old Hag Wood and the village of Doddington. There's some nice countryside views to enjoy along the way.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The estate is dog friendly and a fine place to explore with your pet. Water bowls can be found at the on site cafe. Dogs are not allowed in the Hall, Gardens, Farm Shop, Cafe or Tea Room (assistance dogs only).

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Hartsholme Country Park and the Whisby Nature Park are both located close to the hall. They are both great places to extend your walk if you have time. Just to the east you could pick up the Fossdyke Canal and enjoy a pleasant waterside walk into the city of Lincoln. The old canal path will take you into the city where you could visit the iconic Lincoln Cathedral and historic Lincoln Castle.

display_address: Main Street, Doddington, Doddington and Whisby, North Kesteven, Lincolnshire, England, LN6 4RT, United Kingdom
